review_title: Great place for entry level job
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great PTO and benefit options, good opportunities for career advancement, tuition reimbursement
cons: emotionally taxing work, not super challenging

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
My experience -Great co workers and admins descent salary -but not great overall 
too many managers in roles where they do not know the position but get hired because of their degree and not experience
 seniority means very little
cons:
POA's have no job growth- no upward mobility no flexible schedules in comparison to other similar positions -for those who do not know the role of a POA - it Is to handle and basically manage the entire office similar to an office manager position however MSK does not compensate appreciate or offer any flexibility in the position; that is why no one stays for long and most will leave to work at other institutions 
also during inclement weather be prepared-you are expected to be at your desk on time without hearing a "be safe" or we want you to be careful because you are important to us or a general wish of your well being -no you need to answer those phones it's more important to them then your safety

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Great place to work with advance opportunities
cons: Small hospital but there are a lot of out patients clinics

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: You learn a lot in this role.
cons: The world load can get overwhelming at times.

review_title: Good exposure to research but thankless work for little pay
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: You'll definitely get hands-on research experience, similar to that of a research-oriented masters program.
cons: Clinical research coordinators are undervalued and undercompensated. If you're in this role, know that you will do most of the work for a study (or multiple studies) and get little to no praise or recognition. Most PIs are concerned only with their study accrual numbers and getting their next grant. Burnout is possible in this position. This position is largely seen as a stepping stone to getting into a Masters or PhD program. If that's not one of your goals, I would advise against going this route. However, if you are really inspired by the mission, you might enjoy it. If you are detail-oriented, hyper-organized, self-motivated and prefer behind-the-scenes work you might like this job but only for a year or two.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Benefits salary and team environment
cons: Challenging but fulfilling and worth every bit

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: a little more than NIH standard
cons: It’s expensive for living and working in NYC

job_title: Administrative Manager in New York, NY
pros: Excellent professional development programs from tuition reimbursement (one degree limit) as well as certifications.  I love how MSKCC invites professional speakers and their employees to quarterly assemblies.  MSKCC buys the book in advance for employees (free) to read so you can participate in the presentation and form discussion groups.
cons: Only current employees can see the Grade # for each job posted, which means you do not know if the salary is above $85k (M11) or not.  Do not be afraid to ask the HR contact (telephone) if you cannot find out before applying.

job_title: Advanced Practice RN in New York, NY
pros:
An organization in the midst of tremendous growth.  MSKCC offers much professional development as an RN and the division of nursing has newly acquired ANCC magnet status.  Collaboration with physicians is strong and patient care is held to a very high standard.  Nurses feel
Empowered and respected by patients and medical staff.
cons: Unfortunately space is tight and administration gets a lot of that space creating unfriendly non ergonomic work conditions.  Long days and hard work with inadequate break space and tight staff work space can be difficult over time.  MSKCC is very top heavy administratively and this can be dissatisfying, as decisions are made far from the point of care.  This administrative strong hold has increased significantly over the past 5 years. It has diminished care provider work satisfaction and creates sense of conflict among staff.

job_title: Graduate Student in New York, NY
pros: coffee machines are really nice
cons: couldn't think of any cons

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good company to work for. Salary is higher than some of the other hospitals in the area
cons: Too many to list. I've dealt with HR in multiple capacities and they have not been helpful at all. Everything takes longer than it should and often times, employees try to pass you off to someone else to get things done or just avoid doing work.  I'm disappointed in the environment to help employees be promoted and transfer within MSK. I'd like to think that MSK wants to keep their employees happy and internal, however, that's not what I have found at all, in fact the opposite.  Employees who shouldn't have supervisor positions do, and those who should be promoted and recognized for their hard work, are not. It is very clear that management plays favorites and those who are in higher positions are not judged on their work as those who work under them are. It is truly a shame that this is happening at a great place like MSK. I imagine that this will depend on the department, but I have heard many employees complain about their management with no action ever taken to change the environment here.

job_title: Care Coordinator in West Harrison, NY
pros: Lots of room to advance your career.
cons: I can not think of any.

review_title: Much change needed.  Senior leaders are the problem.
job_title: Clinical Manager in New York, NY
pros: Mid-level managers here are hard-working, intelligent, forward-thinking, good people.  They are ambitious and almost all of them pursue graduate degrees.  It would be great if the company would develop them into future leaders... but this doesn't happen and these people invariably leave for better opportunities elsewhere.
cons:
There are no opportunities for advancement here.  Sure one issue is that no one leaves and so their jobs don't open up.  But the bigger issue is that there is no professional development of any kind; there is no grooming of people to fill/replace/add important positions.  The company doesn't even try.  

Some senior administrators are unethical and intimidating, and this behavior has been tolerated and encouraged. They get away with anything.  When employees see this behavior (and it is very, very visible), it reinforces the notion that there is no fairness and no consequences for bad behavior.  Moreover, these leaders are the very people chosen to "mentor" other people here.  It is a joke.

review_title: Main Campus has room for growth, STAY AWAY FROM THE REGIONAL SITES ESPECIALLY BASKING RIDGE
job_title: Office Coordinator in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: Great benefits, work/life balance at the NY sites
cons:
Management at the regional sites are the worst
There is no work/life balance at the regional's, especially Basking Ridge

job_title: Infusion Nurse in New York, NY
pros: Health Benefits, Pay, PTO, Sick Time
cons: Hostile environment, Bullying, Lack of Care for Nurses. The money isn’t worth it.

job_title: Senior Clinical Research Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Variety of clinical research positions throughout the institution at many different levels.  Starting from the entry level, if you are passionate about the research and the impact you have on patients' lives, it won't take long to move up.
cons: You drive your own experience here, so cons may be in the hands of the employee.  In recent years, the performance appraisal process has changed such that it seems "harder" to achieve an above expectations for tasks/performance that previously resulted in above expectations.  Now, those same tasks/level of performance result in a meets expectations.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
The health benefits are comparable to other companies. 
Many wonderful colleagues. 
Good location.
cons: The  MSKCC experience varies based on who you are and who you may report to. There has been a lack of work/life balance (for some employees). Inconsistent management support and guidance; and significantly poor management decision making.  Unfortunately, I have also witnessed and have been made aware of concerning workplace harassment and inappropriate behavior by some long term employees in management positions. The inappropriate behavior has created an environment of fear amongst the staff and has negatively impacted employee work satisfaction, productivity, and efficiency.  No one should ever feel afraid to report issues and ask for help. Unfortunately however, it is happening at this organization and it is leading to the potential loss of highly skilled employees.

job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros:
-  Full Benefits, Commute Card, Health Insurance, Retirement Savings, Tuition 
  Reimbursement, Online Graduate Programs 
- Orientation is good
-  Competitive salary
cons:
- Cliches and office politics are strong and dominant.  No matter how nice you are to your coworkers or management, if they don't like you your immediately out. 
- These so-called professionals have their own issues, insecurities, and drama they bring to work.  
- Your supervisor will take records of everything you do and whatever you discuss in a meeting will be written up, incase you will sue them. 
- Make sure to read before you sign anything.

review_title: POA position has a shelf life
job_title: Physician Office Assistant II in New York, NY
pros:
MSK is an amazing institution to work for in general. The benefits are incredible, they have a very large amount of discounts to almost anything you can think of and they offer perks through the excellent work/life program. The people here (I can't speak for all of them) are for the most part great. 
The POA (physician office assistant) role is an entry level position and they have a very efficient training program that makes sure that you're completely prepared for your job.
cons: When hire you they make it seem like the opportunity for growth within the hospital is vast. In actuality it's not. There are hundreds and hundreds of people that have the same title as you and maybe 10 opportunities for advancement. (Obviously those numbers aren't 100% accurate but the point is that the chances of moving up in the food chain here is slim to none.) While you do get a "raise" every year based on your performance, it's minimal and doesn't help compensate for cost of living increases in NYC, especially when the economy is so bad.

review_title: RVC Location - Managers run it into the ground
job_title: Client Service Representative in Rockville Centre, NY
pros: corporate benefits, tuition reimbursement, set 9-5 hours in general, the chance to help patients a bit
cons: most Med Onc doctors are nasty and unappreciative, management is terrible - no rewards for good work (praise, recognition or god forbid a raise, like they get in the Commack location), no respect for CSRs from either management or doctors, NO room for transfer or growth; they will block workers from transferring to the city or other locations despite HR claiming that's a great possibility. There was a good manager for some time but she left on medical leave and made it so she never had to return; she obviously knew what kind of place this was. Every month we were told she would be back in a month, until 6 months went by and it was clear they finally needed to replace her. Dysfunctional to the max.

job_title: Clinical Research in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, Reimbursement, Networking with prominent figures in the field
cons:
Many services within the company work differently, are organized differently, and pay differently for the same position. Pray that if you do get this position, you don’t work for a service that completely diminishes your motivation, drive and confidence. If you are so unlucky, and if you are good at what you do, then expect FREQUENT BURNOUT, because you will be given a disproportionate workload compared to your peers who are paid the same. Paid overtime is never in the budget but you’ll find yourself staying late to get work done because you
care about the MDs you work for and ultimately the patients you’re trying to help. Ends up
being time lost that you get no recognition for. Advice to new employees: use this place as a stepping stone to get to the next destination. MSK will never be at a loss and there will always be someone to take your place, so don’t worry about that. 

Unfortunate.

job_title: Clinical Research Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Great colleagues, staff, benefits, and mission. Everyone is genuinely passionate in the fight against cancer and there for the patients first and foremost.
cons: Heavy turnover rate of clinical research staff without adequate coverage strategies in place. As a former supervisor with 15 direct reports it is apparent there is a vicious cycle of employee burnout.  When an employee leave, another takes over their workload "temporarily" or so they're told it will be by their manager. Often times the hiring process is slow and this temporary workload becomes part of the routine workload until that employee leaves and their overloaded workload falls on another employee. Senior staff turnover rate is also apparent which leads to inexperienced managers who aren't quite sure how to overcome archaic processes exclusive to the the center and in no way universal or required in clinical research anywhere else.

job_title: Payment Clerk in New York, NY
pros:
Patient accounts as a whole is a good environment. The managers are good, and leadership really tries to listen to you. 

It’s a good introductory role and you will learn a lot about insurance and the bulk of the money coming into the hospital as long as you show initiative.
cons: The department is a bit disorganized. You have to be a self starter and self sufficient to survive here. There is also not much opportunity for growth which is my biggest complaint. People stay in their positions for decades making it really difficult for people who deserve promotions to get one. Little room to negotiate for salary as well. The morale is also very low even though I didn’t feel that way.

review_title: corrupt  system within the perioperative environment
job_title: Staff RN in New York, NY
pros: Because of the good benefit (only good thing about it), many people take advantage of it (hence always the shortage). My advice to anyone who seeks job here: take advantage of the benefit because you will need it, gain some experience here and if you are a fresh grad, take what you can learn here move on elsewhere after a few years.
cons:
-Corrupted system that reward the compliant with tribal approbation.
-Nursing management normalise sociopathic behaviour and make decency despicable, even good intentions are useless in such environment.
-High turn-over rate since the opening of JRSC. New nursing management highly favors employees who "follows and listens", instead of welcoming diversity and different voices, hence the high turnover rate. New RNs are mostly fresh grads who usually choose to be silent against the management team .
-Closed circle within a high stress environment creates immature behavior among surgeons, PAs and RNs just like high school

job_title: Administrative in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros:
The people you work with are amazing and I always feel welcome and at home
Almost always good support from upper staff
Always new opportunities - activities, benefits, employment, upward mobility
If you are willing to work hard and go above and beyond you will move up quickly!
cons: Sometimes upper management has so much going on that they don't always have time to help (which is totally understandable! It would just be nice)

job_title: Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Pay is good, great benefits, MSK matches what you contribute to your retirement/investments (403B)
cons: Can only speak for the dept  I worked for (Pathology). If you are not a favorite or if you had any type of issue in the past they (supervisors/managers) will hold it against you FOREVER and you will be permanently stagnant, no room for growth to another level position within the dept. Unless you move to a different dept. Supervisors/Managers are too soft to speak or do something that needs to be addressed and/or fixed. The work load for one individual can be overwhelming-one person doing a two man job. They over-all don't seem to care for their employees, only that work getting done and thats it!

review_title: Clinical Trials Office: great place to start, not to stay
job_title: Research Study Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: Fantastic exposure to the clinical research environment for young professionals right out of college; experience working closely with world class physicians; opportunities to interact with patients; opportunities for publication.
cons: Titles and salaries often reflect a fraction actual job responsibilities (especially for entry level positions in clinical research);  promotions often have strict work experience requirements despite obvious qualifications; once on-boarding is completed you are essentially expected to manage yourself; there is little room for vertical movement within a service, most promotions require horizontal and vertical movement (working with a different disease and  new responsibilities).

job_title: POA in New York, NY
pros: None. The POA position isn't as great as they advertise. Most of the staff in that position are uneducated and sound as though they've never passed High school level. For some reason these girls are able to come and go and delegate their work load onto others but when a new person comes along they are under a microscope.
cons: The management is horrible. They are not helpful and or hands on with the training. This is their way of allowing you to sink or swim so that they can fire you before your 6mos and not allow you to collect unemployment. The management staff is sloppy and does not show any compassion when it comes to family and personal lives. When someone has an ill father and is commuting over 2hrs a day to get into work with severe weather, they could still care less as they will hold 5mins against you.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, great coworkers, good facilities. Tuition reimbursement, great vacation accrual, ability to move internally. The best part about working at Memorial Sloan Kettering is that you are contributing to a greater good. Although it is stressful at times - at the end of the day, I felt that my work was truly meaningful. There are great people that work here and are very supportive. It varies by department, but overall I've had a positive experience here. Working on the patient side of things is stressful but rewarding.
cons: It depends on department. POAs are often in extremely stressful situations and do not get paid nearly as much as they should. They also don't have a clear career ladder and managers should assist in finding and promoting growth within MSK. Department can lack organization or support which is also an issue, specifically the research side.

review_title: Fantastic mission, great research work but awful corporate culture
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-People value and support the mission wholeheartedly
-There is incredible research being done by some of the best in their field
-Pockets of incredibly dedicated managers that will stick up for their staff
-Amazing name brand recognition
cons:
-Get ready to play politics because you if you work in "Corporate" you are generally not promoted based on merit or skill, but by how well you play the game
-People will be conducting the same type of work but one will be paid less
-Fragmented culture; depending on what division, area and who you work for, your work environment will vary
-If you are an exempt-level employee, you can expect at least 50 hours/week as the norm; people routinely work 12+hours

review_title: Constantly shifting set of sub-par management in CTO. No leadership.
job_title: Budget & Contract Specialist in New York, NY
pros: MSKCC is known for having great benefits.
cons: The Clinical Trials Office Budget Group is a poorly thought out, abysmally managed department. There are some great staff doing amazing work under a constantly shifting set of unprofessional, poor-quality managers who are completely ignorant of how work gets done and haven't the leadership skills to properly implement changes. This leaves a department with high turnover for staff (approx 50% of the department is currently looking to leave) and higher turnover for management (5 different people have led the department under various titles since 2010).

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great co-workers, excellent tuition re-imbursement, somewhat supportive management, flexibility with school schedule, excellent patient care. You feel accomplished for working at MSK.
cons: If you don't know your $$ worth, you will be low-balled for salaries. You have so many demands for the quality and quantity of work that you produce. However, the compensation does not equate. In addition, it doesn't matter how long you have worked here, in all comes down to who you know in order for you to get promoted. Sad to say, this employer is not as supportive of all races; especially in leadership promotional opportunities.

job_title: Clinical Manager in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, including tuition reimbursement (comparable with other university hospitals).  Salary average to below average for NYC.  Having the MSKCC name on your resume will open other doors.
cons: Overall the organization is good to their patients and staff.  Unfortunately, there are many departments and sub-departments.  If you chose to work there be careful as to where you decide to work.  For example, if you see many openings in the Department of Medicine, Clinical Trials Office, it should be a red flag.  Upper "administrative" management has little regard for staff, or patients with heavy turnaround as a result.  HR and overseeing management turns a blind eye and protects staff that should otherwise be terminated.  Chose carefully your next career move.

job_title: Session Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It's a great way to meet nice people in your 20s/30s. You learn a lot about cancer care and establish connections with patients. You can't bring work home and are not expected to check your email when you are not at work. They pay for overtime. Great health benefits and plenty of vacation time. Coworkers are helpful.
cons: Doctors can be moody. I would like to be paid more, seems like the managers demand more and more out of us but our pay stays the same. Your raise is based on a 'performance appraisal' which is a scale of 1-5, it is impossible to get 4s or 5s. You work with a lot of people, when certain people are slackers, you end up picking up their work because at the end of the day everything needs to be scheduled for the patients.

review_title: Great and supportive organization, but falls to the whims of corporate practices
job_title: Staff Nurse in New York, NY
pros: MSKCC is a great organization. I was a loud and proud employee. As a staff nurse I felt supported by my superiors. I always had appropriate resources available to me to do the best job I could.
cons: Like any hospital, MSKCC struggles with nurse retention. Management fails to hire nurses at a steady rate and waits until a mass exodus happens to fill the gaps. I have heard that until a position is physically vacated, the job cannot be posted by HR. Unfortunately, quantity is valued over quality and my manager hired nurses who were not qualified for my unit. This is one of the reasons I left.

job_title: Senior Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
It's one of the few major employment centers for a non-academic track (i.e. staff) skilled molecular biologist in NYC proper. Most of the pharma companies are in North Jersey or Long Island. But then, the atmosphere is much more relaxed than it would be at, say, Abbott or GSK.
Pay is a notch (or three) above the other comparable academic institutions in NYC.
Also, of course, its high standards of care and noble mission make it a prestigious employer.
Research is very well supported with funding, administrative help, and a beautiful new research lab building.
cons:
This is only personal -- i'm not terribly interested in clinical research so my opportunities are rather limited. But i wouldn't hold that against the institution.
Few other downsides. It's a bit of a hike from the subway, but not as bad as Rockefeller University.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Basking Ridge, NJ
pros: Great company, great incentives and benefits.
cons: Management sucks at the Basking Ridge,NJ location. Absolutely no communication at all among the departments . Nursing management is awful lacks respect and has no interpersonal skills whatsoever. Tacky work ethics among the staff which causes patients to wait hours for treatment not to mention other mishaps. Poor accountability, always passing the buck. Needs improvement major key. To all prospective PCT applicants planning to upgrade their education forget it because the hours you work are inconsistent. Therefore get your degree before you apply. Last but not least there is no room for growth unless you work in administration or at the Main campus in NY. Yes, I said and that's all folks.  The grass is definitely not greener on this side of MSKCC.

job_title: in Hanover, NH
pros: As a first job out of undergraduate school, this was a great experience for anyone who is looking to take some time off between their undergraduate and graduate education. You get exposure to some of the best physicians in their field and amazing cutting-edge research going on at the institution.
cons: Since this is a large institution, there are a lot of young individuals in the same role as you (as a Research Study Assistant), so moving up in the ranks takes a lot of directness. If you want your work to be noticed, you have to work really hard, otherwise you're just another "cog" in the system.

review_title: The MDs are great but management and organization is not
job_title: Clinical Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: Ability to work directly with the leading physicians in the field and make great connections. If you're looking for a good rec letter for med school this is a great place to buddy up to amazing MDs!
cons:
Overworked and under-payed! When I started my team (one of the smallest) was 9 people. Most of them left and we have 6 people doing the same (if not more) amount of work.  At one point we were down to three people. At 6 people management does not seem keen to hire anyone new at the moment. 

Also the work environment is isolating. If you are an extrovert this job is not for you! Most days are spent staring into my computer and do not involve talking to anther person except over email. 

Disconnected from patients.

review_title: Company is 5-stars, but your Dept. matters.
job_title: Research Assistant II in New York, NY
pros:
EXTREMELY competent peers and colleagues. 
Very positive, inclusive organizational culture. 
Comprehensive benefits - health, tuition, retirement
Multiple locations and some fairly flexible work arrangements.
Solid opportunities for researchers with top-tier institutional/tech support. 
Depending on the specific Department, regular opportunities to engage leading researchers and guest presenters.
cons:
There are no major Cons, though I gather some departments are better managed than others. I worked both full-time and part-time in the Dept. of Psychiatry & Behavioral Sciences - 5 stars.

I would strongly recommend this employer to a friend,-especially to STEM-types looking for publication exposure, or strong -NF- idealists looking to work in a hardcore patient-first environment.

The only 'cons' are those applied to hospitals or research, generally.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great team environment; gain real insight into medical practices, great learning environment.
cons: The stress is made tenfold not by demanding doctors, or patients, but administration overseers who show no respect to staff. I had an email I had written to a colleague brought to my attention in a specially called meeting just to ask me why I was so informal in writing...Also my advancement was blocked by same individual even though a doctor had requested me specifically to join his new research lab. Administration needs to trust its own stringent hiring process and trust the individuals who pass it are equipped and willing to do the job (and often perform above and beyond what is asked only because of the drive to deliver outstanding patient centered care).

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Brooklyn, NY
pros: MSK offers truly amazing benefits for yourself or your partner. The community at at MSK is supportive and nurturing, and employees /want/ to come to work every day which completely changes the work atmosphere. The employee resource networks promote inclusion and diversity among all employees, and that support is truly phenomenal. The support for transitioning employees and gender nonconforming patients is admirable.
cons: As a nonprofit, salaries are not high. Sometimes workload vs compensation feels.. less than satisfactory?, however I would not say it's necessarily unfair. Treatment and happiness varies between departments as does your administrative support but the teams that I am a part of have been supportive. I am fortunate enough that my immediate colleagues are people I would like to work with long-term.

review_title: Excellent patient care and research; success of growth strategies is questionable
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Mission-driven and strong, universal focus on cancer.  Aggressive growth plans and lots of available positions.  Promotion opportunities vary by department.  Pay well and have great health benefits.
cons: Each department is managed independently, so interdepartmental career opportunities aren't a focus.  HR and Administration are very political; promotions don't always seem to be based on accomplishments and fair assessments. The "open and fair" environment promised by Leadership is often hard to find.  Senior management may look the other way and/or assume someone else is addressing the big challenges of aggressive growth.

review_title: Terrible experience- don't waste your time!
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Unfortunately, no pros to working at MSKCC.
cons: Working at MSKCC was a terrible experience. They hire hundreds of people at a time because they are constantly firing people at a time. I was accused of "lying on my resume," because I couldn't meet expectations in the first two weeks on the job. In the first two weeks of work, my former boss was on vacation and I didn't have complete access to the location or rooms where I could conduct my experiments, so how could I meet expectations in the first two weeks. One of my coworkers screamed in my face and accused me of lying because I made a common mistake while helping her, she in turn "planted the idea," to my boss which ultimately led to my termination. If I lied on my resume do you honestly think that my references from pervious jobs or graduate school would lie for me too (I think not). MSKCC turns on their employees, don't waste your time. If you had a similar experience please comment or share.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: I enjoy working here because my fellow employees are hard working, around my age and are a pleasure to work with. Additionally, in less than 2 years, I have received a promotion with a $6 raise from when I first started so it is great to have a place where you can advance.
cons: Be careful to read your contract when signing because the terms can change at any time and you may or may not know it. Example: You may have applied for and had been hired for a 6am-2pm job but your contract may say "subject to change," thus, if the company decides to make a 8am-4pm schedule for that same position, it may now be part of the contract you signed and you may now have to possibly work that schedule although that may not have ever been what you wanted when you first applied for the job.

job_title: Research Study Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: I have quite a bit of autonomy and flexibility in my position. I appreciate this, but if you do not enjoy working independently and keeping track of your own deadlines, this is not for you. I have developed close relationships with some oncologists, which affords me numerous opportunities, including authorship on research publication. You determine how much you get out of the role-- it can be quite a bit if you capitalize on your time time, or it can be not as fruitful if you don't take initiative.
cons: Your responsibilities are completely dependent upon the service and department. The duties of a research study assistant in Breast Radiation Oncology are entirely different from the duties of a research study assistant in Urology Surgery. So, it's hard to tell what you're going to get from an outsiders perspective.

review_title: MSKCC is a non-profit medical research mecca with a very corporate attitude.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
-Great reputation among the academic community
-Competitive pay and benefits compared to other regional counterparts (i.e. Mt Sinai, NY-Presby, Columbia, NYU, etc.)
-Not a great place to retire at, but a great career ladder
cons: They get what they pay for and then some.  Although pay and benefits are very competitive compared to other large NON-PROFIT academic communities, MSKCC has a very corporate attitude (heavy-handed bureaucracy, very political, etc).  They are purportedly non-profit.  However, there is high focus on production, publication, cost-cutting, etc.  This translates into obscene work hours (50-60+ hrs/wk) for non-exempt employees that make having a work-life balance difficult.  You may be making more than your medical/academic counterparts, but if you are treated like a corporate cog, you should receive pay equitable to the hamsters spinning the wheels of large pharmaceutical companies, consulting firms, etc.  The great reputation of the place lies in the blood, sweat, and tears of non-tenure track research support staff, coordinators, interns, residents, fellows, scientists, scholars, and researchers.  If you working directly for a drug company or contract research organization, you would be making significantly more for the hours you put in.

job_title: Radiation Oncology in New York, NY
pros: Great institution that cares about its patients and employees. Fantastic support from supervisors and managers. Employees in my department are the most dedicated, mature and intelligent that I have ever worked with. Benefits such as vacation (4 weeks) and insurance are good.  Great cafeteria. Clean professional environment. The only place for cancer care is here!!
cons: Salary could be increased for the quality work that is performed each day. However, overtime does help a bit!

review_title: All the hassles of a not-for-profit and none of the benefits
job_title: Administrative Manager in New York, NY
pros: The people themselves are amazing to work with--most of them are very smart and motivated, at least on the clinical side.
cons: Where to begin?  The administration is scattered and HR is a joke.  Each department is run like its own little kingdom.  When I interviewed, I took a huge pay cut but was promised normal working hours and tons of vacation time.  2 years in and I've never been able to take off more than the occasional long weekend; I have to take "junk" days just to keep my vacation bank from being full.  Also, no sign of a raise or promotion in site.  I'm looking elsewhere.

job_title: RSA in New York, NY
pros: Great co-workers, able to make each other smile even on those difficult days. Management is average. Good to help out the patients and help brighten up their days, some of the workers in other departments are wonderful and treat you like a human being.
cons: Work load is always increasing, and no new policies or procedures to help balance it out. The opinions and suggestions of those actually doing the job is never taken into consideration. Still expected to get the work done even with faulty equipment. For those who do speak up you're branded a trouble maker. Some nurses, doctors, and those making more money than you treat you like garbage, and will try to break you.

job_title: Patient Billing Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Literally none, horrible people, awful supervisors...no encouragement or room for growth
cons: Could not think of a worse company to work for. Supervisors have the ability to LITERALLY blacklist you, so you can interview for other positions, do well, and never be contacted again. Fellow employees are uneducated and rude, and the company does not like when you speak your mind. I worked there for 6 months, was never late, always respectful, and was FIRED because I was deemed "difficult to work with" after creating programs to try to improve everyone's work flows. Utterly absurd.

review_title: Leading cancer center -- could be doing better
job_title: Assistant Attending in New York, NY
pros: 403b and match; subsidized housing for faculty. Generally positive and helpful staff. Location and accessibility to mass transit. Tuition for dependents of faculty.
cons: Tremendous amount of red tape,  bureaucracy, and in some cases duplication of efforts. Insufficient space for research labs; clearly not a "chronic NYC problem" as some administrators would leave you to believe because other area research centers are not nearly as congested or pressed for space. Clinical volume appears to be waning. Personalities and egos at the highest levels of management beginning to negatively impact aspects of the center.

review_title: Great place to work but there is room for improvement
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
excellent benefits/ VAC/ sick time/ maternity + paternity leave.  This is usually where MSK hooks it's employees - for an entry level position you get 21 VAC days which is absurdly awesome.  

There is a lot of opportunities to get involved, attend presentations, gain additional skills through various trainings (L&OD).  

For the most part the employees are nice and driven by working for an institution with a great mission.

Tuition reimbursement caps at 12500/yr - you will not find that anywhere else.  

Pay is fairly competitive. Great work life balance but this is sometimes dependent on what dept you work in (some dept's are known for having horrible work-life balance)
cons:
- Upper management (not your supervisor) decides what people get on their performance appraisals even though they never work directly with you
- Nepotism runs DEEP.  If someone in upper management doesn't 'like you' expect to get looked over for potential promotions for people who are considered 'safe and conventional' (ex: someone who is early, stays quite in meetings, and doesn't challenge the administration even though they might do a subpar job)
- Unrealistic expectations: we are rated on a scale of 1-5 but MSK likes for people to believe that being a 3 ( which ranges from 3.0-3.74 and is considered 'Successful') is something to be proud of because "MSK has much higher standards and being successful here means you exceed expectations everywhere else". 
- There is a moral issue in most dept's because people don't feel like their hard work and dedication is not valued.  No one is asking for an award but when you put in 100hrs in 2 weeks because your dept is severely understaffed you should be appreciated and not receive and email from your supervisor asking you why you did so much OT when they know exactly why
- Everything happens at a very slow pace; from transferring, to being hired, promotions, etc... these could take literal months before anything happens

review_title: Not the place to be if you work with technology
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Flexibility, telecommute, benefits, great physicians
cons:
First of all worth to say that I'm writing this review from the perspective of a Software Engineer.

In a simple sentence, avoid this place if you are in the tech space.

Old mentality, old systems that were developed in the 90s and never updated. Impossible to maintain a conversation about tech (not that I'm a geek or anything).

Nobody (you are reading correctly, yes) does coding. They simply install and use Windows based tools. 

Next->Next->Finish is the closest thing to an algorithm these people have seen.

Honestly, avoid this place at all cost if you are trying to make a career path in technology. Now I understand why healthcare is such a mess; and trust me it is a really big mess

review_title: Incredible center and organization; job-wise, will depend what you do there...
job_title: Development Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is an incredible institution to work for - important mission and some of the most valuable work being done today.  However, like with many organizations, if you don't work for the direct mission of the center, i.e., if you are not a doctor, nurse, or researcher, the amount of time and oversight spend watching over your position is minimal.
cons: As the above, jobs other than doctors, nurses and researchers are not respected or watched over closely.  The Center obviously could not function without those professions above, however, the importance of other departments is overlooked.

job_title: Research Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are good (especially tuition support), and the culture is really great. I felt very valued as an employee and believed in the mission of the organization.
cons: It's hard to start in an entry-level position (especially in clinical research) and then move up the ranks; there are lots of people looking to move up and not that many jobs. However, I felt that management was clear about this when I was interviewing - at the entry level, it's often somewhere that people will work for a few years and then leave to go back to school. That said, there were a LOT of people at MSKCC who had been there for 5, 10, 20, even 50 years, so this may have been unique to my particular position/track. Starting salary is low.

review_title: Fantastic organization to start a career in healthcare.
job_title: Senior Analyst, Clinical Practice Plan in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits; driven coworkers that bring the best out of you; and many opportunities to grow.
cons: As a very large organization, it is a bit intimidating at first. I came in as an RSA and eventually found my stride in the clinical practice plan.

job_title: Client Technology Specialist III in New York, NY
pros: The people at mskcc are wonderful. Many, many employees have been there for years and years, even in IT, which was where I was for a few years. The culture is great, work life balance was nice, but be sure that if you are on call, you are expected to deliver.  Wish I could have retired there.
cons: Unfortunately at my age and stage in my IT career, growth felt limited. I was very specific to what I was doing, and with technology changing constantly, there wasn't much impact I could have in such a large organization.  For this reason, it was the wrong time in my career for me to remain at mskcc.

review_title: OC/POA role: Luck of the draw & inconsistent so it's what you make of it.
job_title: Office Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Decent benefits, camaraderie amongst fellow OCs (misery loves company), challenging role with transferable skills (e.g. multitasking, customer service, conflict resolution, problem solving, general admin, medical terminology, etc.), delayed gratification for working in a difficult speciality.
cons:
The office coordinator role is extremely inconsistent - the job description does not cover the scope of the actual position and responsibilities are vastly different dependent on where you're placed. This position is truly luck of the draw when it comes to the service you're placed in and the clinical team you work with. One person can be placed in an office with a low patient/call volume requiring little follow-up and minimal administrative responsibilities, while another has a much higher volume with continuous communication and active admin duties.
There is a lengthy training process in place to learn the systems; however, most of your learning will come within the first few weeks between mentorship and starting in your office. Job duties vary immensely between services so the training environment is the rose-colored glasses to the reality of what the day-to-day looks like as an OC.
Most offices/clinical teams will consist of the physician, nurse, care coordinator (formerly SA), and office coordinator (formerly POA), but some will also include nurse practitioners, clinical research coordinators (formerly RSAs) and fellows. Depending on your service you may also be expected to actively interact with other services to follow-up on results or referrals.
In summary, there are a lot of moving parts and often the OC is the one keeping track of it all. As the overseer, if anything goes wrong, then the OC is the one who has to find the source of the problem, figure out a solution and implement it, all while keeping respective parties updated, whether that be an angry patient and his or her family, or a stressed out clinical team.
The OC job can be thankless and repetitive; however, you are expected to get through each day with the underlying desire to provide service to your patients and team. While in theory this is admirable, burn out happens quickly and there are little-to-no resources to provide assistance other than staying paid overtime to catch up and taking a vacation if you can find coverage. The caveat is that the coverage system is broken and leaves OCs feeling guilty for taking time off as it inevitably burdens a fellow OC to take on the extra workload.
There is very little upward mobility for OCs. You can go laterally and switch to CC to be in clinic or CRC to be involved in research, upward to a Team Lead (formerly POS) if you can manage to beat out the hundreds of other OCs and external applicants, internally to a different role which you will once again be in competition with other applicants, leave to go back to school, or put in your 2 weeks notice like many do (whether or not you have a new job lined up).

review_title: Great place but management is lacking
job_title: Session Assistant II in New York, NY
pros:
You work around leaders in the field of medicine / oncology so it's really an amazing experience if you are interested in learning more about medicine, science, research , new technology in the treatment of cancer is developed at MSKCC.
Also the patient care aspect is really rewarding, I learned a lot from my interactions with patients and I really enjoyed developing those relationships.
cons: Manager was dysfunctional and treated a few people in a weird manner.  Not a lot of room to advance unless you know people who work there. And even then it seems like you can't branch out to other areas/ fields of the organization

job_title: Fundraising Events Associate in New York, NY
pros: Amazing co-workers, and the events are blast. Great mission and you get to meet and hear incredible stories from participants and donors of the hospital. PTO and benefits are great, management has a high standard of excellence and is very organized. Staff meeting are fun and a great way to stay connected to larger events team.
cons:
During the high season you will work lots of nights and weekends (wasn't a con for me but could see this being so for others).
Because most senior roles enjoy their job, there is slow movement for growth.

job_title: RSA in New York, NY
pros: leadership is great. inspiring doctors and research nurses. dedicated staff in some departments, dedication is definitely lacking in many of the research departments upper management
cons: although some supervisors are helpful and thankful for dedicated workers, many just assume you will do the work you have to do. some supervisors don't even thank you for staying late or offer to help. research department has gone through many changes in the past 5 years. but training and helpfulness need to be reevaluated. hard to get promoted even if you do great work in under a year. bonuses are barely given

review_title: Great stepping stone for people interested in health care.
job_title: Session Assistant I in New York, NY
pros:
Memorial is a great hospital with top notch management. The benefits are great and for an entry level position the pay is competitive. 

A great bonus to working in this organization is educational reimbursement they give to you if you want to go back to school

If you want to get hired in this place I'd recommend talking to someone who is already hired and for them to refer you.
cons: This is not a 9 - 5 job. Some days you'll come in as early as 7am and some days you may have to leave as late as 9pm.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: Everything is great, Salary, Vacation time, benefits. It's hard to get a job here. So when you are here, STAY!
cons: It really depends on you. If you can avoid politics, and bureaucracy then you are good. Mind yourself and do what you are getting paid to do. Leave it at the door when you go home and dont bring your home problems to the work place and you should be great!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: You will definitely be a part of a great mission, and you will gain a lot of valuable skills at an incredibly reputable institution.  Working here is like resume bootcamp.
cons: It really depends on the department. Some departments have more staff, more support, more work-life balance, others just do not. MSK can sometimes rest on a "you're lucky to be here attitude" without valuing employees.

review_title: Research Study Assistant - Department of Medicine
job_title: Research Study Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Interesting research, great connections and stepping stone for a career in research. Good exposure to lots of different kinds of research, as well as what goes into it. Great benefits and vacation time, tuition reimbursement, and opportunities for advancement.
cons: There's sort of a known "expiration date" for being a research study assistant here; most people only stay about 2 years before moving on (to grad school or promotion), so it feels like there's a lot of turnover and constant training.

review_title: Only good if you are a doctor, nurse or high level employee- everyone else watch out
job_title: Secretary IV in New York, NY
pros:
Mostly great co-workers 
Health Benefits for family, Pension
cons: Micromanaged, totally an ideal work place if you are liked by certain key players. Unfair treatment of support staff who are not "in" with the proper people. Seniority stands for nothing here. Also minimal room for growth. Poor service specific training in admin positions. Lack of empathy for employees with families. Scary place to work if you get sick, or need medical treatment for more then 3 days.

job_title: Session Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The patient's are what keeps you going; you bond with them during a difficult time.
cons: The salary is low for the hours/amount of work, little room for growth, staff tattles on every little thing to get you in trouble, very cliquish colleagues, disorganized management, and so on.  If you work as a session assistant on a four day work week expect to be in as early as 6:30am and stay as late as 10pm.  The hours are crazy.

review_title: Amazing company that does not follow the big corporate culture
job_title: Senior Unix Engineer in Lyndhurst, NJ
pros:
I turned down a job here initially thinking a smaller company was better for my mentality. I realized my mistake and called seeing if this position was still open.. and I couldn't be happier it was.

MSKCC cares about their employees VERY much. The work environment is extremely amazing, the people are all amazing, and management is so spot on perfect. This has been the best work environment I have ever experienced and I hope I can spend many more years at this wonderful organization.
cons: None so far. Short of things that are my fault (such as the commute), They really have been a stand up company.

review_title: Good for MDs and PhD students
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in New York, NY
pros: 1st Class institution with very talented and smart PhDs and MDs researching and treating patients. Amazing community
cons: Huge differences depending on research positions (not only in salary). Faculty and MDs are treated like 1st class, PhD students go in business class, and Postdocs go in tourist. MSKCC estimates a postdoc time in 3 years, so you are "invited" to leave the housing after that period, which means you will face NYC Real State with an academic salary. Benefits fall short compared with the high cost of living in the city.

review_title: Amazing people, tremendous room for growth!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: MSKCC prides itself on hiring the best.  You are constantly learning, and wanting to do better because the people you work with are bright and motivated.  There is also a lot of emphasis put on work life balance, with great internal seminars, as well as flexible work arrangements (ie telecommuting, flexible hours, etc).  I have never worked at an institution with such a high retention rate, which says a lot about MSK!
cons: There are several facilities which are brand new, and if you are lucky enough to work in those offices, terrific! However, other off campus offices leave much to be desired.  Buildings are old, with no windows.  Be sure to ask about your workstation before you start!

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in New York, NY
pros: It's a place that challenges you mentally and physically, which ultimately results in spiritual growth. The experiences that I've gained from working here has taught me how to appreciate life and helped find my reason for being. I've also gained a few close friends. They have incentives to further your education.
cons: In terms of career growth for a respiratory therapist, there isn't much to look forward to except becoming a supervisor, manager, or director. Aside from that, there are a few lateral moves that you can make such as switching jobs to work in home care, sleep labs, PFT labs, or long term care facilities. Also, the job won't turn you into a millionaire ;)

job_title: Applications Analyst in New York, NY
pros: MSKCC is a world class cancer research hospital.  You feel like you are making a difference in the fight against the diseases.  Concern for patient satisfaction is stressed.
cons: Some managers are outstanding, while some other managers leave a lot to be desired.  I was fortunate to work for one of the better ones.  Upper management leaves a lot to be desired.  Some at the top appear to be mostly interested in getting personal recognition.  Some administrators are very self focused - everything MUST be their way.

review_title: great benefits, decent support, cruddy laboratory environments
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in New York, NY
pros: post doc fellows get free benefits for self and spouse, admin support is pretty good
cons: aside from undetermined hours, laboratory environment is terrible. the smarter people are, the more childlike politics and games they place. most people in an academic research setting have not worked outside of academics or are fresh graduates that have fallen straight into research, so be aware- they don't understand professionalism, and dont understand the difference between 'friends' and gossip. Many of the bosses or research mentors are quite the same, regardless of their expertise.

job_title: Strategic Planning and Innovation in New York, NY
pros: This is one of the few remaining truly mission-driven healthcare institutions in the US.  Even our CFO puts mission before finances. Senior leadership has offered us opportunities to do more innovative things than anyone might imagine to be reasonable. This is a great institution with a great future in the war against cancer.
cons: Like any large, older institution, MSK has some bureaucracy that can be frustrating at times. It is also true that not all executives are equally effective.  That said, anyone who seeks the betterment of the mission will find their place here.

job_title: Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: They have good benefits and you learn a lot from the company and very diverse people working in the organization.
cons: It’s to many kids working in the company. There needs to be more mature people working in the position. It’s like I am in high school again because of this. This makes the organization look bad.

review_title: A place with passionate fantastic people
job_title: Senior Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Your colleagues will be wonderful and the mission compelling. Lots of resources. A new physician-in-chief who is an amazing leader.
cons: This is a time of change. Several new leaders and it isn't clear if they will be able to work together coherently. There is conflict about how money drives or doesn't drive the place. This is normal in academic medicine.

review_title: Great Cancer Facility but slow growth / opportunities

review_title: Wonderful employer for a recent graduate!
job_title: Session Assistant I in New York, NY
pros: Even though my position is one of the most basic that the hospital offers, I am treated like a valued member of the team and encouraged to grow, whether through advancement into management positions in my current department or observation of and movement into other departments. MSK wants to keep it's employees and is doing a great job of offering a lifelong career path.
cons: Shift hours in my position can cause some issues in coordinating my life outside of MSK. However, this is remedied by my very flexible management team if advance notice is given.

review_title: A fine first job. Compensation is terribly low.
job_title: Research Study Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Incredible doctors and clinical research colleagues - the best in the business. Good health insurance. Many opportunities to learn about cancer and patient care.
cons: Insultingly low pay for the level of work. No financial rewards based on performance (at least in 2017). Given more work than possible to complete. Never able to take lunch or legally required breaks. Burnt out quickly.

job_title: Session Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
Loved my coworkers that I became friends with.
Good first job experience.
Great if you want to go back to school. Some positions have a lot of flexibility and even a 4 day work week.
cons: After POA or SA, there isn't much room to go up. Practice Leader is all about who you know. You can interview until you are blue in the face, but they still won't hire you, they may hire someone that has 1 yr experience versus your 5. It doesn't make sense. There needs to be clearer expectations and not based on who you know, what fashion you were or how blonde your hair is.

review_title: Good company to work for, great benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits, depending on the department you work for, people work as a team and you get work done. They provide varying programs that look after both the employees and patients alike. They are very "big" on health and wellness. Depending on your job title, they have very flexible job schedules.
cons: Room for growth takes a long time, promotion comes if someone leaves or a new position is created. Some departments can be a bit top heavy.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: good benefits from the company, decent amount of vacation days (if you are able to take them), easy to bond with co-workers (over same misery/workload). this job will teach you a lot about yourself
cons:
Dept of medicine is overworked and run extremely poorly. The management doesn't know what the actual days of POAs look like and therefore try and have them do work that is physically impossible for one person. 

The way that coverage and cross coverage is worked out - its extremely unbalanced and unfair (both within certain services and across different services). During my time there I was expected to cover SIX individual doctors offices on any given (regular) day in an extremely busy service. Other services are limited to two phone lines only and if both were in use the phone would go to voicemail, meanwhile there was NO LIMIT to how many phone lines my service had and was usual occurrence that more than one call would come in at the same time and there would be a constant flow of at least two people on hold at all times throughout the day (in a busy office) and we weren't allowed to have any unchecked voicemails throughout the day. Offices themselves and services overall are almost incomparable in workload, which is not fair to employees since all POAs have the same salary "range" and its not based on office or work done. you can be in a 1 MD office that is slow and make the same amount as someone who works for 3 separate MDs that are busy, which is extremely unfair to the employee working in the busy offices; especially when salary isn't great to begin with. 

All POAs get the same (LENGTHY) training but depending on the office or service you are in the way things are done or what you actually have to do will differ. Training should be adjusted for specific services and more tailored to individual POAs (including those who will be covering for those POAs) so the training time can be cut down and you can get people in offices quicker and things could be done more efficiently. 

To take off any days, you need to get another POA to agree to cover your office, which is asking a lot when all of your co workers are just as overworked and busy as you. 

There is little to no room for growth within the actual POA path. POA I to POA II doesn't even count, since they give that to everyone. They say its based on performance but its basically given to anyone who makes it past probation and doesn't have any major complaints about them. From POA II to POA III is essentially useless and non existent, since you have to be there for years and years before you can even be considered and very few people ever make it that long. The only other jump that they offer is a specialist which is basically just managements puppy, who doesn't do anything to benefit POAs or help them, unless its to cover a prolonged absence. They also dont require specialists to be a POA before becoming a POS which is a complete joke since there are literally hundreds of POAs you could promote without going to outside departments or services (there were only about 4-6 specialists for the whole dept when I was there). 

This is the theme for management overall, as upper management is very comfortable with things the way they are (majorly flawed but not their problem since they don't deal with the repercussions) and if anyone tries to change anything or do anything other than whats currently being done, they will never move up or get into a management role. They would rather take people from other institutions (who don't know the internal problems or have any internal experience) and have them follow a script and take over, than promote someone who actually knows where the problems are and what needs to be fixed and give them the power to do it. Management lacks talent because all the smart people leave after seeing the politics and resistance to change in a department with such deep rooted issues. 

There is an unbelievable turn over rate, that management chalks up to this being an entry level job and make excuses about people leaving to go to school or what not, but most of the time that is not true and people are only leaving because they are so miserable there. Within six months of being there you'll be one of the most senior people on the team. 

Even though the POA is absolutely essential to the running of the office and making sure things so smoothly, there is little to no respect from the clinic side (depending on the MD and nurse). POAs are the first to be blamed for everything and the first to be asked to fix everything, regardless of who originally messed something up. There is serious disconnect between the offices and the clinics and SAs and POAs. They paint a picture that everyone works together but on a day to day basis, its just people pushing responsibilities on different people, with responsibility usually falling back on the POA, no matter what even if it is someone else's responsibility. 

As negative as this review is, this job will challenge you and test you and teach you a lot about yourself (if you can survive long enough) but it is definitely not for everyone.

job_title: Office Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: There is dedication to providing patient care in a timely manner; they care about the patients.
cons:
A very large workload; you will often need to ask for help to manage the office, which can be troublesome to other coworkers during busy periods. High pressure to succeed with extremely thin margins of error.
Very low work-life balance, especially if you commute or need to work overtime regularly.

job_title: Clinical Research Supervisor in New York, NY

-"No news is good news" culture, positive feedback is rare and sparse

job_title: Debt Collector in New York, NY

cons: it's a very competitive place to work. That made my experience there very uncomfortable and unwelcoming. I worked in the finance department and I would never like to work there again.

review_title: Best Cancer Hospital....Great Place to Work
job_title: Secretary IV in New York, NY
pros: I love working at Memorial, been here for 17yrs.  Great place to; the benefits are great, they have a lot of resources for employees and excellent care for patients.
cons: Most times good workers are looked over and professional development is not often available to some. You can have the experience to do a job but not the degree so you are deemed not qualified.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Monmouth Junction, NJ
pros: I love the high level of customer service from all of my colleagues. I feel like I'm apart of a ministry. I'm a almost 17yr vet.
cons: It's very difficult to get promoted. Especially in IT. Internal transfers to a higher position after graduating from school is A difficult task to fulfill at this company. HR needs to improve its interviewing process. I've applied for 7+ jobs and haven't even gotten an interview. Smh

review_title: Happy Employees at One of the Best Cancer Centers in the World.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: great benefits , work life initiatives, tuition reimbursement

Management in the department of medicine is atrocious - no accountability for when managers do something wrong or make a mistake. Anything that happens they always try to blame someone for it.

job_title: Flow Cytology in New York, NY
pros: Benefits, Salary (somewhat), employee perks, good location in the city.
cons: Management, HR doesn't really take action, nor listen to the countless employees whom are giving the same issues for why they are leaving a particular department.

review_title: Great Institution, but confusing work environment
job_title: Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: It is a unique insitution that makes real difference to patient lives. Exceptionally professional individuals. Brilliant long term and short term visions, massive expansion and great brand recognition
cons: The management is very confusing. Policies appear to be one-size fits all, whereas there is significant divergence in goals, work profile and requirements for its component parts, namely the hospital and allied services and the research divisions. The patient care centric policies sometimes appear counter-intuitive in a research enterprise and holds it back from higher achievements.

review_title: Strategic Planning and Innovation team great in-house consultancy
job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
Culture is very relaxed on SPI, Strategic Initiatives team.  Great emphasis on developing skills and producing results, with a relatively flat hierarchy - little or no bureaucracy.

Strong quantitative analysis and advanced tools that aren't learned or used in many other places.  

Even at entry level, great opportunity to influence major hospital decisions.
cons: Not many downsides, except pay could be better.

job_title: Research Tech in New York, NY
pros: Depending on who you work for. The work can be exciting and strenuous at the same time. People in general are nice. It's a place to be if you have passion for science. They depend on your self-discipline and integrity. There can be a lot autonomy if you are independent and driven. They are supportive and want to see you succeed.
cons: Not much advancement for Research tech. it's more of a transition position. Eventually, we all move to other places in order to move higher. But it's a great experience if you are not sure where you want to go yet.

job_title: Clinical Dietitian Nutritionist in New York, NY
pros: Rewarding work.  Team work culture. Excellent continuing education plan. Appreacative customers. cons: Occasional silos, hierarchy and delays can detract from productivity in certain disciplines but self starters can navigate.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: It's a fine entry level job. You really do work from 9-5.
cons: Very bureaucratic place to work. Management claims in the interview that it is easy to grow and move around, but it is not. Furthermore, you really have no sense of power as a POA. What management says is what goes regardless of your feelings on the matter. And it's quite draining to talk to patients every day-while some are nice, many others are demanding and you are an easy target for them to take their anger out on.

job_title: Clinical Research Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: Kind staff members to work with who for the most part that are equally dedicated to getting the work done.
cons: Company overall has become increasingly more corporate over the last five years, which has significantly changed the working environment for those who have been at the institution for several years.

job_title: Physician Office Assistant II in New York, NY
pros: There is a lot of room for growth, not only in your particular position but within the entire organization. It is a bit tough to get your foot in the door, but once you are there, they consider you an investment and provide a bunch of different resources that can help you launch a career. MSK spends a lot of time and effort on each individual employee and although it can be a bit smothering at times, they really help you to hone your skills and you will definitely thank them for it. The jobs themselves are also very rewarding because you often have direct patient contact, whether its part of your job or just from walking around the campus, and it is gratifying to be in a place that focuses on giving back to people.
cons: The management is super, crazy bureaucratic and you can feel at time like they are stalking you and because they can use the "patient safety"rule (even when it doesn't apply), it trumps nearly any plausible explanation you could provide for some misdeed (ex: you arrive at your desk at 9:01 instead of directly at 9 because of a train delay or a broken elevator and you are considered late because it could potentially endanger patients that may be attempting to contact your office). The management also tends to be withholding with information, such as not providing you with an answer to an important question of yours until the last minute, even when they have the answer as a form of control. They also tend to squander a lot of time on useless things and schedule a bunch of ironic meetings, such as dragging you out of your office on a very busy day for a half hour lecture to discuss how important it is to stay on top of your work on very busy days. It can be a stressful environment sometimes because you can be criticized for silly things, like if they catch you checking the weather when you have no work to do during one of their surprise flybys, they will ask you if you are on lunch or using company time and then remind you that you are lucky that only they saw it because if anyone else were to see such buffoonery that you could misrepresent MSK to outsiders (which doesn't even make any sense considering this takes place in private offices), but it is just another way to control employees.

review_title: It's better than most but could improve in technology
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The organization has very intelligent and passionate individuals.  Everyone I met is committed to the vision for improving patient lives.  Work roles and hours are clearly defined and most managers protect your boundaries and scope of work.  There are many who have been at the organization for many years, some their whole life which says a lot about how the organization has treated them.
cons:
As much as it is a tribute to the passion and commitment of the organization, the dinosaurs that have been with Sloan for decades are preventing progress towards more effective uses of technology.  The institution is distributed throughout Manhattan, NJ, and Brooklyn but yet the technology to support distributed decision making is what my Dad used in the 80s and 90s.  

Sloan invests in this tool called SharePoint and this other social networking tool that mostly people use to post content that isn't relevant to daily operations.  Yet, there is a world of cloud-based tools that are more effective and do sign business associate agreements that are accessible security via mobile devices.

Sloan is not keeping up with the changes of healthcare in terms of the increased number and complexity of patients in the healthcare system.  While your role is clearly defined, within that definition your tedious tasks grow more and more because the technology we used to communicate and collaborate is outdated.

job_title: Nuclear Medicine Technologist II in New York, NY

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good pay, excellent insurance, orientation, interesting trainings
cons:
Where do I begin?

MSK has an beautiful veneer and presents really well from the outside. Great patient care, world-renowned research, and a seemingly inclusive environment which lead to long careers here. Remember that this is a glossy place and looks great on resumes/CVs. This veneer starts with the orientation. MSK's orientation is the best as it is welcoming and claims to value all employees. I have worked in several NYC hospital systems, and this orientation is a show-stopper.  However, orientation is nothing like what working here is on a daily basis - they want you to believe this is a supportive environment in which innovation, growth, and passion are valued. Nothing could be further from the truth.

I am going to break this down by subject:

Faculty and management - Faculty are deeply out of touch with everyone who actually does the work; this manifests as authoritative and demeaning behavior, operation behind smoke and mirrors regarding grant budgets for which they are the PIs, and a culture built on microaggressions. Moreover, management is petty. They gossip relentlessly, tread around discrimination issues (both LGBT and race), deliberately leave key front-line staff out of the discussions, take credit for lower employees' work, and hide behind many levels of this so-called success framework. Take a look at the morale among front-line staff - it's low. You have a revolving door they attribute to people getting their education, moving, other opportunities. No, the faculty and managers are awful. People leave toxic work environments not because of the work.

Racism - MSK hires POC to fill a quota. This is me and everyone other POC working here. Case in point: I was actually told by faculty that the normal MSK patient is white, upper middle class and has a nuclear family when I questioned the lack of representation of POC/LGBT/different socioeconomic statuses for patients within the area I worked in. This faculty member continued by saying that adding POC and LGBT patients into this project was "too complex" and that "disadvantaged patients" were a hindrance to this particular project. When I brought this to HR, nothing was done. No slap on the wrist for this faculty member. Nothing. This was one of many experiences I had here - yes I documented all of them.

However, white employees get away with being outspoken and unruly. The level of favoritism for white employees is astounding. Take a look at who lasts the longest here, gets promoted, and whose ideas become research, influence clinical care, and are generally taken seriously. 

Homophobia and transphobia - Being a white gay man or woman here seems to be a good thing for the most part. Just enough diversity to be safe. However, if you are a queer person of color, a transgender person, or a non-binary person, stay away. It does not matter that there are employee resource groups at MSK, you do not work with those from the group in daily context. You will find yourself alone and dealing with constant ignorant comments or questions (at the most well-meaning of intentions) all the way up to outright discriminatory statements. MSK is way behind and a damaging place to work for LGBTQ people.

Issues with job descriptions and scope of work - beware of job descriptions that are not truly what they are. While job seekers can never truly have a whole picture until you are actually at your desk in the day to day, it is important to ask exacting questions here as this seems to be a pervasive issue. Ask to speak to others on your potential team about their experiences not just the people you are interviewing with, ask for examples of projects and daily work to make your decisions if you can deal with the racism and homophobia and transphobia.

Many people at MSK have never worked in other environments, and it shows. They drink this Koolaid like they have been in a desert for the past week.  

Bottom line: 

White people will do well here. Come here if you only care about your salary and benefits. But be prepared to be belittled, experience racism, homophobia, transphobia, and have little opportunities for advancement.

Protect your mental health and dignity if you are a Person of Color or an LGBTQ person. There are plenty of jobs out there in research and program management in much healthier environments.
